title: 1.3 My way - tto123
description: Deze les valt onder de arrangeerbare leerlijn van de Stercollectie voor Engels voor tweetalig onderwijs, leerjaar 1, 2 en 3. Dit is blok 1 'Personal'. Het onderwerp van deze les is: My way. In deze les staan (kinder)slaapkamers centraal. Binnen het onderdeel grammatica wordt de 'simple present' behandeld.

items.content:
The subject of this period is your environment.

  • Form groups of three or four pupils.

Discuss the following questions in your group:

  • What does your bedroom look like?
  • What are the most important things in your bedroom?
  • What does your day look like (a normal school day)?
  • What does your day look like in the weekend?
  • What does your day look like in the holidays?

Step

Activity

Aim

Time

Introduction

Find out what you already know.

10

Step 1

Reading
Children's bedrooms

You can understand a text about children's bedrooms and answer questions.

15

Step 2

Listening
A day in my life

You can understand a video and answer questions.

15

Step 3

Vocabulary

You can understand and use vocabulary about bedrooms.

15

Step 4

Grammar
Simple present

You can understand and use the simple present.

15

Step 5

Speaking
Speech card

You can have a conversation talking about your bedroom.

10

Step 6

Writing
An email about your bedroom

You can write an email about your bedroom.

15

Step 7

Evaluation

Reflect on what you have learned.

5

Step 8

Extra
My way

Watch the video.

Children's bedrooms
You are going to read a text about the bedrooms of children.

  • Read the text.
  • Answer the questions.

Children's bedrooms

In the past a child's bedroom had little more than a toy box, a book shelf and a few posters. Today it looks more like mission control at Houston.

Computers, mobile phones, televisions, DVD players, game machines, and other 21st-century toys fill the room, and often make the child's bedroom the most expensive in the house. Britain's 8- to 16-year-olds have bedroom possessions worth an average of £3.300.

But they don't just have hi-tech items. The average child's room also has designer clothes, sunglasses, watches, jewellery, and sports equipment. More than four in ten children have rooms that combine home office, mini cinema, and gym. Nine in ten have a TV, and seven in ten a DVD player. Nearly all of them have a stereo system and six in ten have either a personal CD player, iPod, or MP3 player. One in four has their own computer.

With so much to do in their bedrooms. It is no surprise that children spend more time there than anywhere else in the house. One girl spends so long on her mobile phone in her room that her parents have to text her to speak to her. Another child disappears into his room as soon as he gets home from school and plays on his PlayStation until bedtime.

Children's bedrooms have become their kingdoms. Some families rarely do anything all together. People eat different meals at different times, and watch different TV programmes in different rooms.

prompt.body: Why does the author write that bedrooms look like mission control at Houston?

content.body: There are so many book shelves.
There is so much electronic equipment.
There are so many toys.

prompt.body: What information do you get about 8- to 16-year-olds?

content.body: Girls have more possessions than boys.
Boys have more expensive equipment than girls.
There is a lot of expensive equipment in their rooms.

prompt.body:
What do most children have in their bedroom according to this part of the text?

But they don't just have hi-tech items. The average child's room also has designer clothes, sunglasses, watches, jewellery, and sports equipment. More than four in ten children have rooms that combine home office, mini cinema, and gym. Nine in ten have a TV, and seven in ten a DVD player. Nearly all of them have a stereo system and six in ten have either a personal CD player, iPod, or MP3 player. One in four has their own computer.

content.body: A television
A cd player
A stereo system

prompt.body: Why do children spend so much time in their bedrooms?

content.body: There are enough things they can do
They are sent there by their parents.
They have to do their homework.

prompt.body: What information do you get about the boy?

content.body: He spends all his time at home in his room.
He spends all  his time at home on his mobile phone.
He spends all his time at home listening to music.

prompt.body: What information do you get about some families?

content.body: They eat in front of the television.
They lead their own life in their own rooms.
They do everything together.

items.content:
A day in my life
You are going to watch a video of Ellie Thumann. She shows us a day in her life.

  • First read the questions of the assignment to prepare.
  • Watch the video.
  • Do the assignment.

prompt.body: At what time did Ellie set her alarm?

content.body: At seven o'clock.
At eight o'clock.
At nine o'clock.

prompt.body: What is the first thing she does when she wakes up?

content.body: Check her phone.
Switch off her alarm.
Switch on the radio.

prompt.body: Where does she go when she gets out of bed?

content.body: To the bathroom.
To the kitchen.
To the balcony.
Ice-tea.
Ice-coffee.
Milk.

prompt.body: Why does Ellie use a little bit of make-up?

content.body: She doesn't use make-up when she is on holiday.
She always uses a little bit of make-up.
They are on the beach.
To get some breakfast.
To do some shopping.
To go to school.
It was a little bit cold.
It was very hot.
It was raining.

prompt.body: What did Ellie do at the beach?

content.body: She went for a swim.
She danced with her sister and ran into the waves.
She walked along the beach.
In Brighton
In Los Angeles
In Florida

prompt.body: What did Ellie do in Harbourwalk village?

content.body: She went shopping.
She went to the cinema.
She went zip lining.

items.content:
To be able to do all the assignments correctly, you need to know some words and sentences.
For each theme there are word lists ready in Wozzol, with which you can practice:

Vocabularylist My way
  • Study the vocabulary. (10 minutes)
  • Do the exercise.

Tip!
There are many ways to study vocabulary. You can read the words aloud or copy them.
The most important rule is never to spend more than 10 minutes studying words.
Every minute you spend longer is a waste of time.

content.body:
Fill in the correct word. There are two extra words.
Choose from: bedroom - things in my bedroom - book shelf - disappear - expensive - jewellery - parents - stereo system - surprise - toys

  1. Will you please put those books on the ?
  2. That watch is by a designer, so it is very .
  3. I like to listen to music on my .
  4. One of the is a computer.
  5. My is my kingdom.
  6. It was a big when my dad bought me a DVD-player.
  7. As soon as I come home from school I into my bedroom.
  8. My mum has got designer . One ring is very expensive!

items.content:
Study the section about the present simple.
When and how can you use it?

Present simple


Do the following exercises:

content.body:
Fill in the correct form of the Present simple.​

I (to like) big cities.

Fill in the correct form of the Present simple.​

We (to play) football every Saturday.

Fill in the correct form of the Present simple.​

The Earth (to turn) around the Sun.

Fill in the correct form of the Present simple.​

Peggy (to live) in London.

Fill in the correct form of the Present simple.​

It (to cost) a lot to stay at luxury hotels.

Fill in the correct form of the Present simple.​

We (to have) a shower every day.

Fill in the correct form of the Present simple.​

It (to rain) a lot in winter.

Fill in the correct form of the Present simple.​

They (to start) work at 9 a.m. every day.

Fill in the correct form of the Present simple.​

You never (to eat) breakfast.

Fill in the correct form of the Present simple.

Margaret (to speak) four languages.

Fill in the correct form of the Present simple.​

Tina is a teacher. She (to teach) French to young children.

Fill in the correct form of the Present simple.​

I always (to sit) in this chair.

Fill in the correct form of the Present simple.​

My parents always (to go) to France.

Fill in the correct form of the verb.​

That man (to work) in a shoe factory.
It never (to rain) here in summer.
We sometimes (to walk) along the beach.
This (to be) a very easy exercise.
Mary (to like) the smell of roses.
I (to come) home early every day.

Fill in the correct form of the verb.​

The man often (to hurry) to his work.
You (to look) like Cindy Crawford!
I dance every weekend. Penny every weekend.
I wash clothes on Sunday. Susan clothes on Saturday.
I write letters every day. Dave emails every day.

Fill in the correct form of the verb.​

I box well. Mike very well.
I go to school by bus. Jill to school by bus.
I always kiss mum goodbye. She always mum goodbye.
I mix the eggs with the butter. Jane the eggs with the butter.
I teach French. Mr. Johnsson English.

Fill in the correct form of the verb.​

It every day in the Netherlands. (to rain)
We games every afternoon. (to play)
I in my sleep. (to talk)
He home after soccer practice. (to walk)
Derek many cartoon characters. (to draw)
After running they always a lot of water. (to drink)
We never any snacks after eight o'clock. (to eat)
You Idols every Saturday. (to watch)

Fill in the correct form of the verb.​

Tim many cartoon characters. (to draw).
He at six o'clock each workday. (to get up)
He to work and begins his job at eight o'clock. (to drive)
He to people on the telephone to help them. (to speak)
He doesn't give information until they a few questions. (to answer).
Tim callers their birth date. (to ask)
Sometimes a person incorrect information. (to give)
Tim watching TV after dinner. (to like)

items.content:
Speech cards
Expressions: If you need some extra help, go to your Wozzol account and take another look at the chunks.
Now you are going to have a conversation.

  1. Find someone to work with and use the schedule at the end of the page.
  2. Write down a couple of words to help you during the conversation.
  3. Practise your conversation at least twice.

After practising twice, do the following things:

  1. Find another pair to work with.
  2. Act out your conversation.
  3. Let them write down feedback for you.
  4. Let them do the conversation and write down feedback for them.
  5. Discuss what things were good and what you can do better next time.

Person A

Person B

1

Greet person B.

1

Greet person A.

2

Ask what his/her bedroom looks like.

2

Answer the question.

3

Ask what he/she likes most in their bedroom.

3

Answer the question.
Also ask what he/she likes most in their bedroom.

4

Answer the question.
Ask for some more information.

4

Answer the question.
Also ask for some more information.

5

Answer the question.

5

Ask a question that you made up yourself.

6

Answer the question.
Also ask a made up question.

6

Answer the question.

7

End the conversation.

7

React and end the conversation.

An email about your bedroom
You are going to write an email to a friend from London.
Use the following prompts:

  • Say hello to friend (think of a name).
  • Write about your plans of changing your bedroom.
  • Describe your bedroom.
  • Say something about the colours in your room.
  • Write what's in your bedroom.
  • Think of a question you could ask your friend.
  • Ask about his or her bedroom.
  • End your email.

What have you learnt in this period?
Answer the following questions:

  • What was the easiest part of this lesson?
  • What did you already know?
  • What was the most difficult part?
  • What was new to you in this lesson?
  • What would you like to ask your teacher?

My Way

Frank Sinatra performing "My Way" Live from Madison Square Garden in 1974. Celebrating the 50th anniversary of one of the most iconic recordings of all time!

  • Watch the video.
  • Look the lyrics up online and discuss the lyrics with a classmate.
